regret: Being too shy with the girls
Not finding love in time to be able to have kids before I had lost my ability through hysterectomy.

Believing that it's always psychologically benign to think about any intellectual idea in any situation. 
(including before bed, while listening to friends, while playing basketball, after thinking about it for long enough, etc)
Be more outspoken, mingle with family friends
That I didn't travel or have more fun when I was in my late twenties. I was so focused on achieving at work, getting married, and having kids, that I wouldn't make time to take adventures.
I wish I had been more careful with my body
The way I ended my marriage
not getting my doctorate sooner

Persevering with an extremely unhealthy relationship (where I was all too willing to accept responsibility for us both and she was unwilling to take responsibility for her own wellbeing, and I was unable to deal with this disparity in a healthy way) to the point where I became abusive and was subsequently convicted of three charges relating to domestic abuse. I regret this both in terms of the harm I perpetrated and the consequences for me.
Wasted 2 yrs of my life with someone non committal.  But not to worry I am married and found someone much better.

Not sticking with my original undergraduate college choice and instead ending up at 4 different schools before I graduated. I feel no connection to my alma mater and have no lifelong college friendships.
Anything I have said or when I didn't listen and this hurt someone.  Especially the times I was judgemental and wanted to be right.
Involving myself in a cause with others without any real blood relatives onboard.

Not following God's prompting when considering dating a guy (I did and wish I never had) as well as accepting the job I currently work at. In hindsight, I can see how doing both of these things ended up being the wrong decision. Thankfully, I learned and the 3rd time, listened and obeyed. (I canceled surgery for an issue that seems to be healed.)
Falling in love with someone else when I was married to another person.
Making decisions based on what I TRULY wanted.
Not taking a timeout to spend time with the important people in my life. I have had a tendency to place work responsibilities ahead of my family and others.
Not fully appreciating and enjoying the period of life when my children were young.
NOT leaving my previous job sooner.
Staying in relationships too long
marriage
Letting others tell me who I should be rather than discovering myself out sooner.
Not studying abroad in college
I did not persist at university and in early adulthood with creative writing
That I chose partners whose lives I could make better instead of choosing a partner who would make my life better
Agreed with my spouse to join with spouse's siblings in a family business endeavor. Sibs recently forced us out.

I have let work interfere with my fitness & health... closely followed by spending money on random crap to soothe work stress.... do you sense a theme?  :)
thanks Dan!
That I didn't join the service or go to college.
Not studying abroad in college.
One significant regret I have is not figuring out what my TRUE major in college should have been the first time around...
not finishing my MBA

I wish I would have changed my career a few times while I was still at the entry level stage. I feel like I'm pigeon holed now in my current career, but perhaps I could be a great project manager or salesman.
I wish I would have ventured out to try other things, like the high school musical or golf or tennis or hockey. I think I would have enjoyed them and performed pretty well
Letting someone else take the blame for my wrongdoing
Not visiting my parents/grandparents more when they were alive.

Not spending more time with my grandfather. He was a tough perfectionist however he was also very smart and interesting. I wish I had been braver around him and gotten to know him rather than just popping in and out. He passed away when I was in my early 20s.
Not sleeping more when I was younger and in that vein having a more strict schedule for myself.  I used to stay up very late probably from elementary school on.
Not taking more chances.

I regret being constantly over-committed during my working years, being too busy to spend time at home with my family and generally enjoy life and health. I think it was a way to avoid being responsible for my choices. Now that I'm retired, I'm going slower and enjoying life more, but it is hard to overcome life-long habits.
I didn't learn to speak fluently in another language
Following my heart and not my head!
Not studying abroad while I was in college.
I regret not spending more time playing/practicing the piano and simply allowing it to be a priority in my life.
Not connecting with my grandmother before she passed away. Not getting to know her despite her efforts of trying to get to know me.
Going to (and failing out of) college right out of high school when I didn't want to be in school. Taking out student loans during the time I didn't want to be in college.
Automatically doing what I thought was expected of me, rather than considering what I actually needed to feel happy and fulfilled.
Not spending more time with my near-death mother when she was in the hospital.
I wish I had applied myself more in high school. It may have impacted where I went school, my chosen career, and even where I lived and who I married.
not having kids
I have not saved enough money during my early adult days and it has a significant repercussion on my finances nowadays.
Never found Mr Right
Not spending enough time with my parents when I was in my 30s.
Not investing money when I was younger.
I spent a lot of time getting messed up- smoking weed and drinking too much. I probably could have done less of that and more time pursuing other hobbies.
I regret not learning how to seek help sooner
Not completing my MBA.
Not committing to one thing long enough to master it.
Getting married so young and for the wrong reasons.
Not having more faith in myself.
Having better relationships - with my family and finding that one person to share the rest of your life with.
Getting too drunk on my wedding night

Early in my career (age 22-35), I allowed bad managers to influence how I felt about myself and my work. They held me back from growing and progressing and made me feel that I wasn't measuring up. I wish I had been stronger, bolder, and more confident to stand up to them and call out their terrible management practices, and look for better jobs more quickly instead of staying "for my resume".
Didn’t trust on gut feelings 14 years back and put all myself to execute it..

I accepted a job as an advancement in my career but it involved moving my family and leaving a company I had grown up in.  The new company and area was a mistake for both me and my family and we moved back less than three years later to an area we love but it took an even longer time to get to back to job satisfaction.
I wish I had been more willing to fail; that is, I wish I had been bolder in engaging in situations where I was not likely to succeed, for the sake of learning from the experience.
I majored in Business for a secure job instead of the English I loved.

The one significant regret I have was listening to my high-school guidance teacher who used a graph to illustrate the earnings potential of high school, vs. college, vs. university graduates as a means for me to determine what career I should pursue. I was made to believe that money would be the key driver to my career satisfaction, which as a student who earned minimum wage for 8 hours of work a week seemed a good argument at the time. Anyway, went to university for the typical pre-med courses, instead of college for journalism which I had wanted to do, because he told me I was too smart for college. I spent the next 15 years of my life trying to find a job that I wanted to stay in for more than 1 year. When I found out that this guidance counselor had committed suicide 5 years after I graduated high school several years later, I was even more regretful that I didn't follow my own inner voice. My lesson learned was to ensure that I didn't place my failed dreams or expectations on my son's when choosing a career, and they took their time before pursuing more formal education, and they are content and committed to the choices they made for themselves.
Caring too much what others think of me

You know - the funny thing is that I have always regretted a lot of things in my life - but when I got this question from I gave it som serious thought and now I can´t really say that I really regret anything. Preveously I thought of regretting not getting into the school I then wanted. Saying no to a job offer. 
Now the only thing I can say that I really regret is beeing to harsch on my twin girls when they where kids.

Concentrating on my career for three decades and only realising later in life about starting a family, (in hindsight not a bad thing as would not have found my partner to enjoy being a father with and a focus on enjoying every moment).
Not consistently following my heart over my mind in some career decisions.

Once, as a child, I made an innocently intended remark that I MUCH later realized must have been extremely hurtful to my Mother. I regret that I made the remark, and also that I never found a way to apologize that wouldn't have made things worse by bringing it up.

I regret not going after my PhD the first time through grad school at the "traditional" age.  As a first-generation college student and a female studying Physics in the early 90's, I was intimidated by it.  I earned one later at 41, but the regret remains.
I did not join the military when I was younger. I’m 32 now.
I felt pressured to marry my ex-husband. We should've dated a bit longer before tying the knot.
Not accepting sooner that my depression and anxiety couldn't be cured, but could be adapted to in ways that allowed me to do work I care about and remain close to people I love.

Making a career move to Germany (from Holland) which my gut instinct told me not to do. Rational thinking made me decide to do this. 10 months later I was back in Holland having quit the job. I regret it in the sense that i would not do it again, if I was in the same position. But I don't regret it in learning from my decision making and what I find important in the career vs life balance.
I have never studied  abroad only in Germany. I had the chance but was too shy to go for it.
Not being open to opportunities that came along when I was on my pre-determined path in University. Think outside the box!

Being so afraid of change/the unknown. 
- Moving to a different state, going for that new job - big changes I was initially horrified of because I didn't know how they would turn out, but none of them were near as big a deal (or as terrible) as I made them out to be.
I should have had therapy sooner
Being passive for far too long.  Embrace the fear and move on.
I didn't take my wife's mental health issues more seriously before we had children.

My biggest regret is screwing up my life to the point that I had to give up my kids. They've been living with my parents for 12 years now. After all the screwing up, my health decided to get interesting, so I haven't even been able to visit them in 3 or 4 years. I talk to my daughter every Sunday afternoon. I've talked to my son once in the last two and a half years; he's in a therapeutic boarding school after a suicide attempt. I look back and wonder where everything went wrong.
That I didn't go to film school.

One of my biggest regrets in life was staying in a relationship longer than I should have. It was the kind of relationship you know is toxic and leading nowhere, but you stay out of fear of being alone. My partner needed me more than I needed them, we both knew it, but we stayed together because I was scared I wouldn't find someone else who would love me. I found that it was more damaging to stay in the relationship for a variety of different reasons. Some of those reasons included: my partner was financially draining, and psychological damage. The day I ended our relationship was the best decision I ever made for myself. I felt bad, and still do to this day, and the only thing I regret is leading this person on and not ending things sooner.
Not valuing myself soon enough - not doing as well as I could have in school (to fit in) which impacted everything and settling for the wrong relationships.
I wish I had started my 401k straight out of school.

I wish I had spent more time with my grandmother before she died. In the end, she wanted the freedom of death and that was such a scary and sad thing to me that I ran away from it and avoided her. I regret that I didn't have the courage to accept her where she was and be a companion anyway.

Two regrets: 

I regret not taking academics more seriously in college. I have a great career and make great money compared to others, but I could have made more opportunities for myself.

Regret not asking for help early in my career. People want to help you. I did not learn to ask for help until I had a few painful professional experiences. I've learned from them :-)
Not quitting that job sooner
Not taking more risks earlier in life - exploring the world, meeting more people, following my heart into adventures that didn't "fit the box".

I am not being glib but I do not have a significant regret. I have not had a perfect ride but I am happy with my outcomes and my relationships. I have many things I could have improved on in a do-over but I hope I learned something from them! The thing I have said to friends is that I guess when I took the "path less traveled by" I actually could have / would have enjoyed taking BOTH paths. There is so much to see and do. But you choose, and play the hand you are dealt, right?  Enjoy every sandwich as Warren Zevon said.
That I didn't get out of a marriage that wasn't making me happy sooner. I was afraid to let go and be alone.
Staying in a job for too long - just waiting for that progression or moment of opportunity that never came.

It's difficult to regret something because I know everything led me to where I am now. For example, I might regret that I was so inconsiderate while making plans to travel around the world, resulting in my boyfriend breaking up with me. But then I might not ever have moved to South Korea, and I believe I would have regretted never fulfilling a dream to live abroad. 
I guess my biggest regret would be stressing over things that already happened and getting upset/anxious. Feeling bad about choices I already made. It doesn't feel good, and it doesn't help. It’s a waste of time and energy, and it distracts from enjoying the present moment. Better to look at the experience with love and forgiveness, and figure out if there's anything to be learned.

I regret not having focused my career on one rather obscure topic that I was passionate about and could become a serious expert in over 30 years such that I could feel my expertise is really valuable at the end of my career and would give me as sense of being in demand even as I pass traditional retirement age.
Making a decision based on what I thought other people might think, instead of basing it on my own feelings.
I regret not being more confident and comfortable with myself so i could dress the way i wanted and do the things i wanted to do.
Not taking more chances / being bolder
